comments.commentBody: MapQuest? That's not a service, it's a cruel joke: the longest, least obvious route to any destination.
No Fields.  He signed with Toronto.
This is  a good solution for attentive parents who don't want to share their bed. My mother always had a crib, and sometimes a child's bed in her room.

JMR, I'm sure you mean well, but your comment is fairly WASP-culture centric. No, the main responsibility/ambition of parenthood for many is NOT to produce independence. In many other countries, values like community, harmony, and patience are valued and independence and self-reliance are seen as undesirable personality traits (for example, in my husband's home country in Asia). In many countries (including Western ones) it's considered abhorrent to separate mother and child (particularly mother and baby!) while sleeping. Only Americans seem to feel the need to enforce "independence" on an infant or toddler. This doesn't mean those who do not are shirking some sacred duty.

I find your other tips to be good ones. But let's not sully your pragmatic advice with cultural imperialism. Many of us Americans come from very different backgrounds, and claiming your cultural beliefs are the "goal" of parenting is pretty rude.
To Elizabeth A: Re my comments being WASP-culture centric; actually I'm Jewish.

Surely one of the main responibilities/ambitions of parenthood is to produce independent, secure, self-assured and self-reliant people?
Allowing children to share their parents' bed seems to me to be a step in the wrong direction. I have raised five children who all, at one time or another, had a sleeping problem. The way we did it was to have a mattress by the child's bed where we could lie near them, pat them and talk to them but they had to stay in their own bed. It didn't seem to take very long - the longest was about a week - before they learned that they didn't really need to be physically close to us to feel secure enough to go back to sleep. Re barfing etc - we had a rubber sheet over the mattress so changing sheets was easy. Oh and a spray bottle full of slightly scented water was used to scare away monsters when that need arose. My children use the same methods for the grandchildren.

I haven't used Mapquest on a smartphone. But when I've used it on plain old web interfact, it's always been superior to Google maps. Gave more intuitive directions, for example more sensitive to the signs you see on the highway (not only giving you the highway number but literally the "sigs" that you'll see ahead of you) than Google maps, which was more mechanical about things.

When I get my new iPhone, I will be trying out Mapquest before any other mapping app, because I trust it.

Reminder: if Sheed had been in shape in 2010, the Celtics would have beat the Lakers for the championship. But Sheed was fat all season, tried to work into shape during the playoffs, had a couple of decent games, and had nothing in the tank in the game 7 where both teams staggered up and down the court. Again: Sheed having just a littloe conditioning before the season stats in 2010, and the Celtics have 1 more ring and the Lakers 1 less.

And? He hasn't played since.

Yeah, that's going to end well.

Don't have a smartphone and don't use apps but do use my desktop a lot to check locations and MapQuest is the only one I've ever used from the very beginning. Okay, Google Earth if I want a "real world" look at a location, but for just a map, MapQuest every time.

Then again, using online mapping/direction tools in conjunction with the GPS function on a phone incorporates a host of variables that cannot exist on a physical map. Traffic volumes, speed limits, and construction are all used to compute optimum routes giving gps/online tools a distinct advantage. How about in Boston where one way streets can make a nightmare of even the simplest navigation? I'd give online tools an step up for that as well. Maybe older people are clueless about making the most out of technology to drive the most expedient route, not necessarily the "shortest."

I second the comments of zulh8cf and add:

I use MapQuest -- prefer it, usually, over Google -- but never print out the directions. I merely take a pen (remember those?) and jot down the main roads and turns I have to watch for. In big, easily read, print. Circle turns; underline road/routes; use other gimmicks so that I can spot my next moves (if I have to) while I drive.

Easy, if one has still-functioning brain power. (And no GPS voices to annoy the heck out of me.)
Navigation detaches people from the surroundings they inhabit making people unaware and uncaring of their environment.

Article states: "Most people are more likely to associate MapQuest with stacks of paper, printed out from a home computer, most likely by their parents." That's because their parents are smarter. If you look at an actual online map, you can see the route it's giving you and adjust it to take the best route. However, if you just follow ANY gps directions with blind loyalty, I guarantee any trip will take MUCH longer than it has to. Young people today are clueless about reading maps or how to drive the shortest route.

If only it were so. I am afraid I must agree with the critical mass in the app store Mapquest reviews. This is a clunky, ad-filled, not infrequently inaccurate map app. MotionX GPS Drive, Scout, Waze, or even the work-around Google Maps are all better choices at this point. For Google Maps go to maps.google.com, and follow the pop-up directions to putting an icon on your home screen. It's not elegant, but it works until Google produces a finished app.

Mapquest is a bust as far as I'm concerned.  And Google is still #1 in my book. Forget phone apps.  Using my computer it took five attempts in Mapquest to find my address (that has existed for over 50 years).  It worked finally when I removed the suburb name from the search. And, in satellite view the magnification was something like four orders less powerful than Google.

Apple collects data about teir Maps app usage - just as Google, Microsoft, MapQuest, et al do - in order to improve the product. It's a necessary step. Siri works (or doesn't as the case may be) the same way: they need more voice analysis in order to improve the algorithm.

Sometimes the motives are exploitative, and sometimes they are unavoidable to improving the service. I'd argue in this case it's the latter.

The Brooklyn Bridge melting in 3D view. Give me a break!

Overblown.

The Playbook is great, they just had horrible marketing when it launched, and not a lot of apps, and obviously, no native email or calendar.

But to be honest, if BB10 is similar to Playbook 2.0 (which now has email and calendar and a good number of apps), then I'll be pleased. The Playbook is surprisingly intuitive. I bought it a few weeks ago up here in Toronto when it was dropped to $149.99, and it's turned out to be better than expected. Once you get used to the swiping, you can really rip around on it quite easily.

I have been unable to access my PNC account now for 48 hours!
This is not trivial to me.
Even my branch "customer" computer didn't work this
AM.
This is bigger than you are reporting.
Why is the NYT playing this down?

I understood that Yale President Bart Giamatti brought Yale out of the red and into the black by not replacing senior faculty in the same numbers, with the result that graduate students began teaching what junior faculty had previously taught and Yale's advantage over Harvard in terms of access to senior faculty and having them as teachers of small classes disappeared.  On the other hand, at least back then, Harvard clearly had superior library resources to Yale's.  So there were obvious differences of that sort then.

California cancelled the otherwise nationwide subsidy of schools by property taxes on (mostly) the middle class and the wealthy. Proposition 13 a generation ago fixed property taxes at 1% of the most recent sales price.
This amounts to about 20% of what other states collect locally for schools.

The result is that California primary education is tied for last place with Mississippi financially, and is lagging educationally. Many of us think that the change was not a step in the right direction. We also voted not to legalize and tax marijuana last year, also a step in the wrong direction.

www.youtube.com/tra1776 especially Inequality

Kevin,

The man would have to be generous and empathetic to know the meaning and depth of true devotion to country. Ronney, it seems, does nothing that isn't calculated to bring him some benefit. In the case of war with Iran, he'd derive the glory.

He's a scary man.

Thanks for this link. One sees this kind of documentation on the Daily Show with Jon Stewart, but rarely if ever in the mainstream media and I keep asking myself why? If the Daily Show writers can dig this stuff up every day, it can't be that hard.

http://www.cheesefoodnation.com

I haven't seen any Romney ads, so maybe his are good too, but I've now seen at least a couple of Obama ads (thanks to posters like you) and they are killer. Just pure genius.

They must make Romney's blood boil with rage.

Thanks for posting.

sean
That video was funny.

A large part of Romney's game plan is to lie, and hope no one notices. By saying that he expects Obama to lie in the debates, I think Romney is making a miscalculation. Because of this statement it will be difficult for Romney to lie in the debates because everything he says in the debates will be so closely watched and can be used in campaign ads against him.

And of course if Romney has to stick to what is normally thought of as the truth, he loses.

For a preview of the kind of trouble Romney could have in the debates - see the Obama ad - Mitt Romney's Crocodile Tears
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUycqixNLxA

The ad begins - Mitt Romney says he expects the President to say a lot of things that aren't accurate at the upcoming debates.
Because of constituent services, incumbency is a huge advantage for Congressional Representatives. Polls may show general disregard for Congress, but individual representatives are usually popular.

The problem with this approach is that it envisions Democrats joining Republicans in rooting for a slightly less robust economy. At this point, however, an improving economy gives the impression that the economy is improving in spite of the worst that the Republicans could do to bring it down. That puts a feather in the Democrats' hat.

I still don't understand why these worse numbers would not have an adverse effect on republicans in congress, when a good number of people are well aware that it is their blocking of any legislation that would undo the Bush/Republican damage that is causing our economic problems.

The implication is that people are all in a vacuum and have no clue what causes their bad circumstances but will all, en masse, take it out against the president. That doesn't seem extremely plausible, even if in 2010, that's exactly what happened, in part, I believe, because the president was not making any effort at the time to properly point the finger at those republicans to blame.

I agree. Although I also think some of it his experience. He's spent his life talking to small demographic groups: the rich, CEO's, investors, Mormon's, Mormon leadership. So he's personable aroud people like that. Problem is he has never related to common people and is clearly not comfortable with a general audience. Obama has a completely different experience, and it shows. Bush grew up rich but was good at relating to common people, even if his policy didn't show it. Regular folks could identify with him.

To add just a bit to LordTwang's thoughts: In '88, when Dubya was working on his father's campaign, he showed that he remembered the names of people he'd met briefly, a month before, and he remembered details about their family and stuff. For all his linguistic challenges and incurious intellect, the guy was a natural politician.
Mitt Romney, in contrast, doesn't seem to be a natural *anything*.
Artist, I think he's a pretty natural vulture, myself.

Often, on the stump or when he's interviewed, Romney's speech is hesitant, stilted -- as though he's struggling to remember the script, or the agreed-on position. (A task no doubt made harder by the head-spinning pace at which he's changed position on important issues.)

Romney on video at the Boca fundraiser could hardly be more different -- confident, relaxed, colloquial, at ease with his kind of people at the $50,000 a plate event, and not having to strain to remember the script, presumably because he is saying things he actually believes in.

To John Gregory:

Yes, disgraceful on both sides. The Democrats have been attempting incessantly to demonize Romney, and the Republicans have been attempting to do the same to Obama, and I don't like it.

I think you're correct that Romney was simply conflating a number of things in explaining why 47% of the country won't vote for him. You seem more perceptive than most here, although that's nothing to brag about, I think you'll agree.

I'm not a Republican, by the way. Never have been.
Oh, really. I don't think he's nearly that clever.
Huh?
Well said Craig!

comments.userDisplayName: LBJ's Rolling Over in His Grave
comments.commentBody: Nick, Here's the problem with your logic.  47% of a nation not paying any income tax is NOT sustainable.  Federal income taxes RUN the govt.  Everybody pays sales taxes on just about every purchase.  If you're human, you pay sales taxes, so that's not significant.  Everybody with a job pays the 7.65% FICA and Medicare tax, that money is paid to fund the same worker's retirement entitlements.  Nothing special there.  Property taxes help fund the local government's expenses, so they are used to benefit the public, so that's good, but individual federal Income taxes primarily fund the federal government, and the fact that so many Democratic voters do NOT pay any is a real problem for the nation's future well-being.  You guys may "win" the election, but the nation loses if the percentage of non-payers continues to increase.
Lol, facetious often?
